childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1971-1983

You were born the year the Pentagon Papers exposed government lies about Vietnam, the 26th Amendment lowered the voting age to 18, and Nixon took the dollar off the gold standard. The adults in your life were watching institutions crumble while telling you everything was fine.

Your childhood was peak analog. Three television channels, and you had to walk across the room to change them. Saturday morning cartoons were the week's highlight. If you missed a show, you missed it forever—no reruns, no recording, no streaming. You learned patience because technology demanded it.

You were two when Watergate hearings started, four when Saigon fell. Your earliest memories probably include gas lines and your parents arguing about the economy. Inflation was eating the family budget. The optimism of the '60s had curdled into the malaise of the '70s, and that became the backdrop of your childhood.

You were eight when Three Mile Island almost melted down. Nine when Iran took American hostages. Ten when John Lennon was shot outside his apartment. Your childhood wasn't sheltered—it was a front-row seat to American decline. You learned early that the world was dangerous and adults were winging it.

Your toys were simpler. Atari 2600 arrived when you were six, and it felt like magic. Star Wars hit theaters when you were six, and it rewired your imagination. You played outside until the streetlights came on. You rode bikes without helmets. You drank from garden hoses. Either you were tougher, or you were just lucky.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. The name came from a Douglas Coupland novel that captured your generation's sense of being undefined, unmarketable, and vaguely disappointed. You're roughly 65 million people in the US—smaller than the Boomers before you, smaller than the Millennials after.

Your generation was the first to be called 'latchkey kids.' Your parents were working, divorced, or both. You came home to empty houses, made your own snacks, watched too much TV, and figured things out alone. This wasn't trauma—it was just Tuesday. You became independent because nobody was around to do things for you.

You're the generation that doesn't trust institutions. You watched Watergate unfold, saw Vietnam end in humiliation, lived through stagflation, and entered the workforce during the savings and loan crisis. The message was clear: the system will let you down, so you'd better have a backup plan.

Gen X is the middle child of generations—ignored by researchers, overlooked by marketers, stuck between the massive Boomer and Millennial cohorts. You're fine with it. You learned to entertain yourself. You don't need the attention.

Your defining cultural moment wasn't a single event but a mood: irony, detachment, and a refusal to be earnest. MTV, grunge, Quentin Tarantino, The Simpsons—your generation's art was self-aware, skeptical, and allergic to sincerity. You weren't apathetic; you were protecting yourselves from disappointment.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year A Clockwork Orange disturbed theaters, The French Connection won Best Picture, and 'Joy to the World' by Three Dog Night topped the charts. It was a strange year for pop culture—darker, weirder, less optimistic than the decade before.

Your childhood was the late '70s renaissance. Star Wars in '77 didn't just change movies—it gave your generation a shared mythology. You were Skywalker's age. The Force was real if you concentrated hard enough. Every stick became a lightsaber. You probably still feel something when you hear that opening crawl.

TV in the '70s was All in the Family arguing about politics, M*A*S*H making war seem meaningless, and Happy Days pretending the '50s were simpler. You watched The Brady Bunch reruns and knew even then that families like that didn't exist. You learned irony before you learned long division.

Your teenage years belonged to MTV, which launched when you were ten. Music became visual. Madonna, Michael Jackson, Prince—they weren't just musicians, they were images burned into your retinas during hours of watching videos because what else were you going to do? You saw Thriller premiere. You remember where you were.

By high school, John Hughes was making movies about your actual life—suburban ennui, parental neglect, the desperate need to be seen. The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles, Ferris Bueller's Day Off. These weren't just movies. They were documentaries of your interior life, somehow projected onto multiplex screens.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Intel released the first microprocessor, Ray Tomlinson sent the first email, and the world's first pocket calculator cost $395 (about $3,000 today). Technology existed, but it was expensive, clunky, and mostly for nerds and corporations.

Your first encounter with personal computing was probably the Apple II in 1977 or the Commodore 64 in 1982. You learned to code in BASIC because that's what the machines spoke. You typed programs from magazines and debugged them line by line. This wasn't a class—it was survival.

You were thirteen when the IBM PC launched. Eighteen when the Macintosh tried to make computers friendly. Twenty-two when Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web. Twenty-four when Mosaic made the web something normal people could use. You watched the internet go from science fiction to science fact in your twenties.

Your generation straddles the analog/digital divide more completely than any other. You remember typewriters and carbon copies. You remember life before answering machines, before cell phones, before email. But you also adopted each new technology as it arrived. You're fluent in both worlds.

By the time smartphones arrived, you were in your late thirties with mortgages and kids. You didn't grow up with the internet—you grew into it. This gives you a perspective younger generations lack. You know that all this technology is optional, that humans survived millennia without notifications, that 'offline' used to be the default state of existence.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were three when Nixon resigned. You probably don't remember it, but you grew up in its shadow. Watergate taught your generation that presidents lie, governments cover up, and the system protects the powerful. This wasn't cynicism—it was observation.

You were eight when Three Mile Island nearly had a meltdown. Nine when Iranian students took American hostages. Ten when Reagan was shot. Eleven when the AIDS epidemic started killing people nobody in power seemed to care about. Your childhood wasn't innocent—it was a series of crises nobody explained.

You were eighteen when the Challenger exploded on live TV. Nineteen when Chernobyl irradiated half of Europe. Twenty when the stock market crashed on Black Monday. Your transition to adulthood was one disaster after another, and you learned to keep going anyway.

You were twenty when the Berlin Wall fell. Twenty when Tiananmen Square happened. The Cold War ended during your early twenties—the existential threat that had defined your entire childhood evaporated in a few years. It felt like the future might actually be okay.

Then the future arrived. You were thirty during 9/11. Old enough to remember when airports were pleasant, when flying didn't require removing your shoes, when America felt invincible. The attacks happened, and everything changed—security became surveillance, war became permanent, and the optimism of the '90s curdled into the paranoia of the 2000s.

You were thirty-seven during the 2008 financial crisis. By then, you probably had a mortgage, kids, responsibilities. You watched the economy implode and wondered if everything you'd built would survive. For Gen X, this was just another system failing. You'd expected it all along.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the late '80s or early '90s, during a recession. Companies were downsizing. The corporate loyalty your parents enjoyed was already dying. You learned early that employers would cut you the moment it made financial sense, so you'd better be ready to jump first.

Your generation pioneered the concept of 'free agent' career management. You didn't expect gold watches and pension parties. You expected layoffs, restructuring, and 'right-sizing.' You kept your resume updated and your network warm because the job you had today might not exist tomorrow.

You watched Boomers above you clog the management pipeline for decades. They weren't retiring. They weren't moving aside. Gen X waited, and waited, and waited for leadership opportunities that never quite arrived. By the time positions opened up, Millennials were being fast-tracked over you.

You're the most under-represented generation in corporate leadership. Somehow you went from 'too young to lead' to 'too old and out of touch' without ever getting your turn at the wheel. This is annoying but also kind of on-brand. Your generation never expected fair treatment.

Your work ethic is pragmatic. You'll put in the hours, but you won't pretend the company is a family. You've seen too many 'families' lay off half the staff during a bad quarter. You work to live, not live to work—a distinction your Boomer bosses found confusing and your Millennial reports find inspiring.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You grew up with phone calls that had to happen at specific times because nobody carried phones. You dated people you met in person—at school, at work, at bars—because the internet didn't exist. You wrote actual letters to long-distance partners. You know the specific anxiety of waiting by a landline for someone to call.

Your generation married later than your parents but earlier than Millennials. You probably got married in your mid-to-late twenties, the last generation to do so before weddings became financial impossibilities for people in their twenties.

If you divorced—and Gen X has high divorce rates—you probably did it before your kids were grown. You watched your parents' marriages fail and wondered if you'd do better. Some of you did. Many of you learned that commitment is harder than it looks.

Your communication style bridges generations. You can text, email, Slack, and Zoom, but you also remember when 'reach out' meant picking up a phone. You find younger generations' phone anxiety baffling. You find older generations' resistance to email exhausting. You translate between worlds.

Friendships for your generation are smaller circles, deeper connections. You didn't have social media to maintain hundreds of superficial relationships. You kept the people who mattered and let the rest drift away. This was healthy, though you didn't know it at the time.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Your first economic lesson was the '70s stagflation that squeezed your parents. Your second was the early '90s recession that greeted you at the workforce door. Your third was the dot-com crash. Your fourth was 2008. You've been burned by the economy so many times that you flinch when good news arrives.

Your financial psychology is defined by skepticism. You don't trust that the good times will last. You save more than Millennials (because you could afford to) but invest more cautiously than Boomers (because you've watched too many bubbles pop). You're neither optimistic nor pessimistic—you're prepared.

You're the last generation that might actually retire with something resembling security. You came of age when 401(k)s were new but still functioning, when houses were expensive but not insane, when wages hadn't completely decoupled from productivity. You squeezed through before the door slammed shut.

Still, you're sandwiched between generations with competing demands. Your parents are aging and may need support. Your kids are struggling in an economy that's worse for them than it was for you. You're funding retirement, eldercare, and your adult children's stability simultaneously.

The wealth gap between Gen X and Boomers is real but smaller than the gap between Millennials and Boomers. You accumulated assets when they were still somewhat affordable. You're not rich, but you're not drowning either. You know how lucky that makes you, and it feels strange to call survival 'luck.'

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's biggest weakness is mistaking cynicism for wisdom. You learned to distrust institutions, which was appropriate, but sometimes you distrust everything, including the possibility of improvement. Skepticism protected you; calcified, it becomes a cage.

You've normalized going it alone. Independence was survival in latchkey childhood, but in adulthood, it can become isolation. You don't ask for help because you never learned to expect it. This makes you resilient and lonely in equal measure.

Gen X's ironic detachment was protective armor in the '90s, but it aged poorly. You mock earnestness, but earnestness is sometimes what gets things done. Your younger colleagues' genuine enthusiasm for causes might seem naive, but at least they're trying. Irony never changed anything.

You've been the quiet generation for so long that you forgot how to make noise. Boomers demand attention. Millennials complain loudly. You just... dealt with it. This stoicism is admirable until you realize that resources go to whoever yells loudest, and your generation forgot to yell.

Your relationship with technology is both strength and limitation. You adapted to digital life, but you remember analog fondly—maybe too fondly. There's a temptation to dismiss new platforms as fads, new communication styles as shallow. Sometimes you're right. Sometimes you're just being the old person you swore you'd never become.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1991-2001): You entered adulthood during a recession, then rode the '90s boom. The internet emerged. The Cold War ended. Everything seemed possible. You probably landed your first real job, moved to a city, dated people who were wrong for you, and slowly figured out who you wanted to be. The decade ended with Y2K panic and a contested presidential election. Ominous, in retrospect.

Your 30s (2001-2011): This was supposed to be your 'settling down' decade, and then 9/11 happened. You were thirty, probably with a mortgage and maybe kids, watching the world change permanently. The wars started. The housing bubble grew. You bought a house because that's what you were supposed to do, then watched home values collapse in 2008. By decade's end, you were forty, scarred, and significantly more cautious than you'd been at thirty.

Your 40s (2011-2021): Recovery, slowly. The economy stabilized. Your kids grew up. You probably hit your peak earning years. You dealt with aging parents, teenage children, and the existential weight of middle age. Then COVID hit when you were forty-nine, proving once again that stability is temporary. You pivoted to Zoom, monitored your kids' remote schooling, and wondered if anything would ever be normal again.

Your 50s (2021-2031): You're in this decade now. You're either thinking about retirement or laughing at the concept. Your parents need more care, or they're already gone. Your kids are adults navigating an economy worse than yours. You're senior enough at work to have power, or you've checked out entirely. This is the decade where you either coast toward the finish line or reinvent yourself entirely. Either is valid.

Your 60s and beyond (2031+): Retirement—if you can afford it—will look different than your parents' version. You might work part-time, consult, or finally do that thing you've been putting off. Social Security exists but doesn't cover what it used to. Medicare helps but doesn't solve everything. You've survived recessions, pandemics, and technological revolutions. You'll survive this too, probably while complaining about whatever teenagers are doing.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.6 million people born in 1971. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US—smaller than Boomers, smaller than Millennials, perpetually overlooked.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you got a raw deal. They bought houses when they cost two years' salary. You bought houses when they cost five. They had pensions and job security. You got 401(k)s and layoffs. They're retiring with wealth. You're hoping the math works out. The good news: you won't live long enough to see the full consequences of the world they're leaving behind.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more cynical and less vocal about it. They graduated into the 2008 crater; you at least had a decade of decent earnings first. They struggle with housing; you probably own something. They're drowning in student debt; you came of age when college cost less. You have sympathy for their struggles and mild irritation at their complaints about problems you also faced but didn't tweet about.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically from another planet. They've never known a world without the internet. You remember when it arrived. They communicate in images and video. You still prefer email. They're more anxious, more online, more aware of systemic problems. You're not sure if they're more fragile or more honest. Probably both.

Your life expectancy is 77-79 years, slightly lower than it was projected when you were born because progress doesn't always progress. You've already lived through more economic crises, technological revolutions, and cultural shifts than any generation since the Greatest Generation. You've adapted to all of it, quietly, without much credit. That's fine. You weren't doing it for the recognition anyway.

year_events: First email sent by Ray Tomlinson
